public/favicon.ico.description:
The image is a purely visual, highly stylized 3D illustrationâ€”no text or labelsâ€”designed to serve as a brand-entry or logo-type element for the Voder pre-launch site. Centered on a pitch-black background, it depicts a gently rounded cube, its edges softly chamfered so the form feels almost organic rather than mechanical. The cubeâ€™s faces are translucent, revealing a network of sinuous, wave-like strands of light flowing just beneath the surface. Those strands pulse in a cool teal-blue hueâ€”evocative of the â€œSoft Teal Glowâ€ accent in the brand paletteâ€”and subtly shift in brightness, as if liquid or energy is circulating within the form.

Highlights and reflections along the cubeâ€™s top and side faces give it depth, while the interior glow lines create a sense of motion and intelligence, hinting at the productâ€™s core promise: seamlessly transforming abstract intent (prompts) into concrete structure. There are no harsh edges or bright color contrasts beyond the dark background and glowing lines, reinforcing the minimalist, premium, and cinematic tone described in the brand guide. The overall effect is one of calm confidenceâ€”a quietly living object that draws you in without shoutingâ€”perfect for introducing the â€œVoderâ€ experience before any copy or navigation appears.

assets/mockups/brand-entry.png.description:
This image appears to be the very first view of the Voder pre-launch siteâ€”the â€œbrand entryâ€ or hero frame that sets the mood for what follows. Hereâ€™s whatâ€™s on screen:

â€¢ Background & Overall Feel  
  â€“ A deep, near-black canvas (the â€œVoder Blackâ€ surface) fills the screen, giving a sense of infinite space.  
  â€“ The lighting is subtle and cinematic, with just enough detail to suggest depth without revealing any distracting textures.  

â€¢ Logo / Title  
  â€“ Centered near the top is the word â€œVoderâ€ in crisp, white letters.  
  â€“ The typeface is clean and geometric, evoking the modern sans-serif headlines defined in the brand guide.  

â€¢ 3D Cube Illustration  
  â€“ Below the logo floats a gently rounded cube, its edges soft rather than sharp.  
  â€“ The cubeâ€™s faces are translucent with a muted teal-blue glow dancing beneath the surfaceâ€”thin sinuous lines that pulse and flow, as if energy is circulating inside.  
  â€“ Highlights and reflections on the cubeâ€™s top and side faces add dimensionality, while the interior strands of light create an almost living, breathing quality.  

â€¢ Tagline / Caption  
  â€“ Under the floating cube, in the same white text, sits the question:  
      â€œWhat if your prompts were the source?â€  
  â€“ This line uses generous letter-spacing and balanced margins to align with the siteâ€™s minimalist, premium tone.  

â€¢ Purpose & Tone  
  â€“ There are no navigation menus, forms, or calls to actionâ€”just a quiet invitation to scroll further.  
  â€“ The effect is one of calm confidence and intrigue, hinting at a system that can turn simple â€œpromptsâ€ into meaningful structure.  
  â€“ Together, the black-field layout, glowing teal accents, and terse copy function as a high-trust, cinematic introductionâ€”exactly the kind of teaser experience the prompt files describe for Voderâ€™s brand entry.

assets/mockups/closing-moment.png.description:
This image reads like the final â€œcurtain-callâ€ screen of the voder.ai teaser. Itâ€™s laid out on a nearâ€pitch-black field, with just a very faint, softly glowing pool of cool teal light at the very bottom as a subtle accent. No photographs or iconsâ€”only text, all in white, set in a modern geometric sans-serif.

â€¢ At the very top-center sits a single word, â€œVoder,â€ in large, bold letters.  
â€¢ Below that, centered and in a smaller weight, is the brandâ€™s signature line: â€œThe Compiler for Prompts.â€  
â€¢ A little further down comes a quiet promise, â€œComing soon.â€  
â€¢ And at the bottom-center, resting just above that teal glow, is a whisper-small attribution: â€œBuilt with Voder.â€

Everything is vertically stacked with generous spacing around each line, reinforcing a minimalist, premium feel. There are no buttons, nav links, or other UI elementsâ€”this is purely a brand stamp and a final sign-off, designed to leave the viewer with a sense of calm confidence and anticipation.

assets/mockups/logo.png.description:
This image presents a single, softly glowing 3-dimensional cube suspended against an almost pitch-black field. There is no text or other elementsâ€”just the cube and its dark backdrop. Hereâ€™s what youâ€™d notice if you couldnâ€™t see it directly:

â€¢ Shape & Form  
  â€“ A geometric cube with gently rounded edges and corners, so that it reads as both precise and organic rather than harsh or mechanical.  
  â€“ Its six faces are semi-transparent, giving the impression of frosted glass or a very thin membrane.

â€¢ Internal Detail & Lighting  
  â€“ Beneath the translucent surfaces you can just make out a network of flowing, wave-like ribbons of light. These strands trace smooth, curving paths from one face to another.  
  â€“ The glow is a cool teal-blueâ€”bright enough to be clearly visible on the dark background, but never garish or high-contrast, more like a quiet pulse of energy.  
  â€“ Wherever those internal ribbons touch the â€œwallsâ€ of the cube, the surface itself brightens in a small soft bloom, drawing your eye to the fluid motion inside.

â€¢ Surface & Material  
  â€“ The outer faces are subtly reflective: you can see very faint highlights along their top and side edges, as if a distant light source is grazing the form.  
  â€“ There is no specular â€œshinyâ€ glossâ€”these reflections are muted, contributing to the premium, almost jewel-like quality of the shape.

â€¢ Background & Mood  
  â€“ The background is an uninterrupted near-black. It frames the cube in a void, giving the object the feeling of floating in space.  
  â€“ There are no gradients, patterns, or other distractionsâ€”just the negative space that emphasizes the cubeâ€™s quiet presence.

â€¢ Purpose & Use  
  â€“ It reads like a brand-entry illustration or an advanced â€œfaviconâ€-style icon: abstract enough to suggest mystery and conceptual depth, yet concrete enough to feel like a standalone logo symbol.  
  â€“ Its minimalist composure and kinetic interior imply a system thatâ€™s intelligent, adaptive, and energy-drivenâ€”perfect for introducing a product whose core promise is â€œturning prompts into structure.â€  

In short, this is not a literal photograph or diagram, but a polished 3D emblemâ€”its glowing interior and muted, translucent shell working together to evoke a sense of calm confidence, premium design, and latent motion.

assets/mockups/metaphor.png.description:
This image is a full-screen â€œmetaphorâ€ slideâ€”part of Voderâ€™s narrative journeyâ€”set against a near-pitch-black backdrop. Everything is rendered in shades of white and light gray to maximize contrast and maintain a minimalist, cinematic feel.

Layout & Structure  
â€¢ At the very top, centered, is a large headline in a crisp, serif-inspired typeface:  
  â€œYouâ€™ve been in the passenger seat.â€  
  It reads like a statement of fact, inviting reflection.  

â€¢ Below that sits a simple, flowing line diagram. A thin, curved path connects four evenly spaced nodes:  
  â€“ The first node, labeled â€œIdea,â€ is a solid white circleâ€”bright and prominent.  
  â€“ The second node, â€œDesign,â€ is a slightly dimmer circle in light gray.  
  â€“ The third node, â€œCode,â€ is another pale gray dot further along the curve.  
  â€“ The final node, â€œShip,â€ is a faint circle at the far right.  
  A smooth, single-stroke line weaves through these points, suggesting forward momentum from conception to delivery.

â€¢ Farther down, two lines of body copy in a clear, modern sans-serif appear:  
  â€œTools like Copilot and Cursor help you steerâ€¦ but youâ€™re still  
   stuck giving directions.â€  
  This text sits in medium-weight white, split onto two lines for readability, and softly fades into view.

â€¢ Beneath that is a closing question in a slightly heavier weight:  
  â€œWhat if your system already knew the destination?â€  
  This line is brighter and bolder, serving as the rhetorical pivot toward Voderâ€™s promise.

Color & Contrast  
â€¢ Background: pure Voder Black (essentially #000)  
â€¢ Headline and body text: Paper White (#FFFFFF) for maximum legibility (19.6:1 contrast)  
â€¢ Diagram line and dots: light gray tones (â‰ˆ Cool Grey #C6CBD4) to distinguish them from text without overpowering  
â€¢ No other huesâ€”keeps the focus on the narrative and ensures WCAG-compliant contrast.

Purpose & Tone  
This slide conveys the core metaphor (passenger vs. navigator). It highlights how existing tools still leave you â€œgiving directions,â€ then teases the idea of a tool that already â€œknows the destination.â€ There are no interactive controls visible hereâ€”just a cinematic, scroll-triggered snapshot meant to emotionally frame Voder as more than an autocomplete or code helper.

ARIA & Accessibility Notes (as per spec)  
â€¢ Background illustration treated as decorative; critical text is plain HTML  
â€¢ Headline is a semantic h1 (or h2 depending on hierarchy)  
â€¢ Body copy uses paragraph tags with sufficient line spacing  
â€¢ Motion tied to scroll, with `prefers-reduced-motion` fallback disabling any animated path drawing  

In essence, this visual is a distilled journey line: Idea â†’ Design â†’ Code â†’ Ship, overlaid with crisp copy, all designed to make the viewer feel like theyâ€™ve been relegated to the passenger seatâ€”and to set up Voder as the vehicle that will finally let them take the driverâ€™s position.

assets/mockups/outcome-focus.png.description:
This frame is the â€œOutcome Focusâ€ slide in the Voder teaserâ€”essentially a benefits overview laid over a deep, near-black canvas. Hereâ€™s what youâ€™d see:

â€¢ Background & Mood  
  â€“ A very dark backdrop (almost pure black) with just a whisper of texture or vignette at the edges to keep it from feeling flat.  
  â€“ No busy patternsâ€”everything is about contrast between light copy and dark ground.

â€¢ Benefit Lines (Bullet List)  
  â€“ Four concise value statements, each introduced by a familiar emoji icon rather than a heavy graphic. From top to bottom you get:  
    1. A small rocket (ğŸš€) followed by â€œDeliver faster without losing controlâ€  
    2. A target symbol (ğŸ¯) and â€œAlign product, brand, and tech from day oneâ€  
    3. A light-bulb icon (ğŸ’¡) and â€œIterate on ideas, not implementationsâ€  
    4. A circular arrow (ğŸ”„) and â€œMake fewer handoffs. Create fewer misunderstandings.â€  
  â€“ Each line is set in a clean white sans-serif with generous spacingâ€”enough room that your eye easily jumps from icon to text without feeling crowded.

â€¢ Anchor Headline  
  â€“ Below the bullet list sits the big, bold payoff line in oversized type:  
      â€œOutcomes, not overhead.â€  
  â€“ This is the focal pointâ€”large, white, and centered horizontally, giving a sense of calm confidence.

â€¢ Supporting Subtext  
  â€“ Directly beneath that headline is a smaller, lighter-weight line of copy:  
      â€œVoder bridges the gap between strategy and shippingâ€”without adding layers, delays, or drift.â€  
  â€“ Itâ€™s set in the same white tone but with reduced size and weight, serving as a clarifying tagline.

â€¢ Typography & Color  
  â€“ All text is pure white (Paper White on Voder Black) for maximum contrast and legibility.  
  â€“ The font feels modern and geometric (in keeping with the brandâ€™s Inter/Satoshi styling).  
  â€“ The emoji icons add a spark of color (red, yellow, teal, etc.) but are used sparinglyâ€”subtle accents rather than screaming blue or green.

â€¢ Layout & Purpose  
  â€“ Vertically stacked, center-aligned content that reads like a Persuasive List â†’ Pillar Statement â†’ Elaboration.  
  â€“ No navigation or controlsâ€”this screen exists purely to crystallize â€œwhat you getâ€ by using Voder (speed, alignment, iteration, simplicity).  
  â€“ Itâ€™s the narrative bridge from the â€œprompt-driven demoâ€ into the final brand stamp.

Overall, itâ€™s a minimalist, high-contrast benefits summary that uses simple icons and bold copy to reinforce the idea that Voder is about delivering real outcomesâ€”no extra overhead.

assets/mockups/problem-space.png.description:
This image is a full-screen â€œProblem Spaceâ€ slide set against a near-pitch-black background. Centered in the frame is a three-line block of white and off-white text:

  1. A large, bold headline in pure white:  
     â€œThe problem isnâ€™t your tools.â€

  2. Immediately beneath it, a secondary heading in a slightly lighter white/grey:  
     â€œItâ€™s the gap between your ideas and your implementation.â€

  3. Below that, a descriptive paragraph in mid-weight cool-grey text:  
     â€œDevelopers stitch together frameworks, boilerplate, and brittle glue code â€” all to approximate what you actually meant.â€

Surrounding this central text are faint, decorative representations of code fragments and UI elements, all rendered in translucent white outlines and text. You can make out little â€œwindowsâ€ labeled things like â€œwebpack.config.jsâ€ or bits of pseudo-code such as â€œvar App.esx import pathâ€¦â€. Hand-drawn style arrows thread between these fragments, and on the right you see two tiny boxes labeled â€œUIâ€ and â€œREST APIâ€ with arrows connecting them.  

Nothing in the background is meant to be read in detailâ€”these ghosted panels and lines simply evoke the sense of chaos and fragmentation that developers face when stitching together disparate tools and files. The pure white and cool-grey text stands in stark contrast to the dark field, driving home the message that the real obstacle isnâ€™t any single tool but the gap between intent and implementation.

assets/mockups/prompt-driven-iteration.p.description:
This is not a photograph or a product screenshot but a highly stylized, narrative-driven UI mock-upâ€”one of the â€œscenesâ€ in Voderâ€™s scroll-based home page. Itâ€™s laid out on a very dark canvas (near-black fading to a deep charcoal/violet at the edges), with three translucent panels floating against the void.

1. Top-left â€œpromptâ€ panel  
   â€¢ A small, softly rounded rectangle, barely lighter than the background.  
   â€¢ In the upper corner a grey label reads â€œTone,â€ and below it, in bright white text, â€œCasual, confident, modern.â€  
   â€¢ It evokes the idea of a prompt editor or input cardâ€”what you feed into Voder.

2. Center-left headline panel  
   â€¢ Below (and slightly in front of) the prompt card sits the primary message area.  
   â€¢ A giant, high-contrast headline in a modern serif reads:  
       â€œChange the prompt.  
        Not the team.â€  
   â€¢ Beneath that, in mid-weight cool grey, is a two-line pitch:  
       â€œWith Voder, your intent drives product delivery.  
        No briefs. No handoffs. No misalignment.â€  
   â€¢ The text sits in generous white space, its crisp letters floating as if on a stage.

3. Right-side UI card  
   â€¢ Another softly rounded rectangle, slightly larger, containing a mini â€œproductâ€ or â€œlandingâ€ panel.  
   â€¢ A bold statement in white sans-serif declares: â€œBegin your journey.â€  
   â€¢ Below it is a single, pill-shaped button edge-outlined in muted grey with white text: â€œGet Started.â€  
   â€¢ This panel dramatizes the result of changing the promptâ€”an instant UI transformation.

Across all three elements, corners are rounded, outlines are subtle, and all text is either pure white or cool-grey against the nearly black backdrop. There are no additional graphics, icons or navigation chromeâ€”just these floating cards. The overall effect is a quiet, cinematic tease of how Voder can reconfigure a UI simply by tweaking a single text prompt.

assets/mockups/the-why.png.description:
This image represents the â€œWe Believeâ€ or â€œThe Whyâ€ hero frame of the Voder pre-launch siteâ€”a full-screen typographic statement rather than a navigation, form or interactive widget. At its center sits a two-line headline in crisp white, set in a generous, modern serif or semi-serif face:

  â€¢ â€œWe believe software  
     should start with intent.â€

Beneath that, in a smaller, lighter-weight sans-serif, is a two-line subheading:

  â€¢ â€œNot code, Not files, Not frameworks.  
     But the spark behind them all.â€

All text is center-aligned and rests against an almost black canvas (a very deep navy that reads as pure black) with a subtle teal-blue glow and soft gradient arc sweeping in from the bottom right. There are no other graphics or UI chromeâ€”no buttons, no scroll hintsâ€”just a calm field of dark space and white copy, conveying a minimalist, premium tone. The overall effect is to pause the viewer, focus entirely on the brandâ€™s core belief, and invite scrolling to the next section.

assets/mockups/vision-flow.png.description:
This is a minimalist, vertical flowâ€diagram set against a near-black canvas. All content is center-aligned and arranged in four stacked tiers, each tier consisting of a bold heading in white and a brief explanatory line in a muted gray. Between each tier is a single, thin, softly glowing vertical bar in a pale teal hue that visually ties the steps together.

From top to bottom:

1. **Source Prompts**  
   â€“ Heading: â€œSource Promptsâ€ (large, white, geometric sans-serif)  
   â€“ Sub-text: â€œIntent lives in markdown prompts.â€ (smaller, cool-gray, light weight)

2. **Voder**  
   â€“ Heading: â€œVoderâ€ (white, same style as above)  
   â€“ Sub-text: â€œVoder interprets and compiles your vision.â€ (cool-gray)

3. **Application Code**  
   â€“ Heading: â€œApplication Codeâ€ (white)  
   â€“ Sub-text: â€œCode is written, structured, and versioned â€” for real.â€ (cool-gray)

4. **Working Product**  
   â€“ Heading only: â€œWorking Productâ€ (white, large)

The glowing teal bars serve as connectors, lightly illuminating the path from top to bottom. There are no other graphical elementsâ€”no icons, boxes, or backgrounds beyond the dark fieldâ€”so the eye is drawn straight through the four stages of the process. The overall effect is both cinematic and schematic: it reads like a high-level system diagram, emphasizing a smooth, linear progression without any visual clutter.

public/assets/preview.png.description:
This image reads like the very first â€œbrandâ€entryâ€ screen of the Voder pre-launch site. Hereâ€™s how it breaks down:

Overall Layout  
â€¢ Full-screen, edge-to-edge pitch-black background (the â€œVoder Blackâ€ canvas).  
â€¢ Vertically centered composition with generous negative space above and below.  

Top: Brand Name  
â€¢ The word â€œVoderâ€ sits near the top, in large white letters.  
â€¢ The type is a modern, geometric sans-serif (consistent with the brandâ€™s Inter/Satoshi headline fonts).  
â€¢ No other UI chromeâ€”just the name as a bold, confident identifier.  

Center: 3D Object  
â€¢ A softly rounded cube floats in the exact middle of the frame.  
â€¢ Its faces are translucent, with faint rippling waves of light pulsing just beneath the surface.  
â€¢ Those internal flows glow in a cool teal-blue hue (echoing the â€œSoft Teal Glowâ€ accent), giving the object an almost living, liquid quality.  
â€¢ The cubeâ€™s edges are subtly chamfered, and gentle highlights on the top face catch an implied light source off-screen, creating depth without harsh reflections.  

Bottom: Tagline  
â€¢ Below the cube, centered, is the line of copy:  
    â€œWhat if your prompts  
     were the source?â€  
â€¢ This text is in crisp white, using a clear, modern sans-serifâ€“matching the brand voice: minimal, direct, slightly sly.  
â€¢ Itâ€™s set with balanced line spacing and left-aligned under the cube so the two short lines read as a single thought.  

Colors & Contrast  
â€¢ Background: deep near-black, providing a ~19.6:1 contrast with white text (WCAG AAA).  
â€¢ Cube interior glow: soft teal-blue, never overpoweringâ€”just enough to read as an accent.  
â€¢ Text: pure white for maximum legibility.  

Purpose & Tone  
â€¢ Feels like a cinematic teaser shotâ€”no navigation, no form fields, no buttons.  
â€¢ Invites the viewer to scroll, building intrigue: you see the brand, the mysterious cube, and a question that sets up the productâ€™s central promise.  
â€¢ Matches the specâ€™s â€œBrand Entryâ€ section exactly: calm confidence, minimalism, a 3D logo-style object with a glow accent.  

Matches the Prompt Files?  
â€¢ Yes. The brand name, cube illustration, background color, accent hue, and exact tagline (â€œWhat if your prompts were the source?â€) all align with the â€œBrand Entryâ€ mockup specification.  
â€¢ No unexpected elementsâ€”there are no scroll hints or controls, and the typography and spacing feel generous and premium as described.

assets/mockups/logo-light.png.description:
The image is a purely illustrative, icon-style graphic that reads like a brand-entry or logo mark rather than a photograph or UI screenshot. At its center floats a softly rounded hexagonal-prism (cube) shape, rendered in luminous teal-blue tones. The cubeâ€™s faces are semi-translucentâ€”almost as if carved from frosted glassâ€”and within each face you can see gentle, wavy bands of light pulsing beneath the surface. Those interior strands swirl and undulate in darker and lighter shades of teal, suggesting a flowing, almost living energy at the heart of the form.

The cube itself has no harsh edges: each corner and face blends smoothly into the next, giving it an organic, almost tactile quality. Narrow highlights trace along the edges and folds, catching an imaginary light source just off-screen and reinforcing the sense of depth and volume. The glow from the cube softly halos outward, subtly illuminating the surrounding area.

Behind the cube, the background is a uniform field of near-black speckled with extremely fine blue and green digital noiseâ€”think of a very high-contrast static or starfield effect that never distracts but adds a quiet texture. There is no text, no buttons, no other graphical elementsâ€”just this single, centered shape on a dark canvas.

Purpose-wise, this graphic functions as a high-concept emblem or teaser logo: it conveys minimalism and premium quality, hints at dynamic, internal complexity (energy, data, or â€œpromptsâ€ brought to life), and sets a cinematic, futuristic tone without saying a single word. Itâ€™s exactly the kind of visual identity piece youâ€™d expect to see as a pre-launch â€œbrand entryâ€ for a product like Voderâ€”calm, confident, and slightly mysterious.

static/voder-logo.png.description:
This image is a pure-visual brand-entry elementâ€”a softly rounded, translucent cube floating against a near-black background. Thereâ€™s no text, UI chrome or navigationâ€”just the cube itself, centered in the frame. Its faces are sheer and slightly misted, revealing a network of glowing, wave-like strands beneath the surface. These interior lines are a cool teal-blue (matching the â€œSoft Teal Glowâ€ accent), varying in brightness so they read as flowing liquid or circulating energy inside the cube. The edges of the cube are subtly chamferedâ€”no harsh right anglesâ€”so the overall form feels organic and calm rather than mechanical. Highlights along the top and sides catch just enough light to give the shape depth, but the emphasis remains on the interior glow and the sense of â€œintelligent motionâ€ within. 

Purpose and context  
â€¢ This is clearly intended as a hero or â€œbrand entryâ€ visualâ€”a cinematic teaser rather than an illustrative graphic or icon.  
â€¢ It corresponds exactly to the placeholder 3D cube described in the specification (e.g. assets/mockups/cube.glb or the favicon description in public/favicon.ico).  
â€¢ No text or logo overlay appears here; in the final site that layering (logo, headline, skip-link) would animate in around or on top of this cube.

Brand & accessibility check  
â€¢ Colors align with the brandâ€™s palette: deep black background (#0A0A0A) and teal-blue glow (#24D1D5).  
â€¢ Thereâ€™s no text to evaluate for contrast or legibility.  
â€¢ The lack of flashing or high-frequency motion makes it appropriate for `prefers-reduced-motion` usersâ€”it could simply render as a static still if needed.

Anything off-spec?  
â€¢ Nothing here conflicts with the prompt files. All detailsâ€”translucent faces, interior â€œliquidâ€ strands, gentle pulseâ€”match the brand entry sectionâ€™s 3D description.

static/preview.png.description:
This image looks like a heroâ€section mockup or teaser graphic for the Voder pre-launch site. Itâ€™s divided into three visual tiers:

1. Top: A single wordâ€”â€œVoderâ€â€”set in large, clean white sans-serif typography (semi-bold weight). It sits centered against a near-black background, immediately establishing the brand name without any extra adornment or navigation.

2. Middle: Below the wordmark is a three-dimensional cube floating in space. The cubeâ€™s faces are slightly rounded and translucent, with softly chamfered edges. Inside the cube you can see undulating, wave-like ribbons of light in a cool teal-blue hue. These internal strands of light appear to pulse or flow, lending the object a quiet, living quality. Subtle reflections and highlights on the cubeâ€™s surfaces give it a sense of depth and dimensionality against the dark field.

3. Bottom: Centered underneath the cube is a short question in white text: â€œWhat if your prompts were the source?â€ The line breaks into two centered lines, reinforcing a classic hero-text layout.

Color & Mood  
â€¢ Background: almost pitch black, possibly a very deep navy or charcoal (consistent with â€œVoder Blackâ€ or â€œDeep Navyâ€ from the brand palette).  
â€¢ Accent Glow: soft teal-blue ribbons inside the cube (matching the brandâ€™s â€œSoft Teal Glowâ€ accent color).  
â€¢ Text: pure white for maximum contrast (AAA compliance for readability).

Purpose & Context  
This composition reads like a combined brand-entry + hero screen. The 3D cube serves as the visual â€œteaserâ€ or logo motif, while the tagline below hooks viewers with a strategic question.  

Spec Mismatch Call-out  
â€¢ In the written specification, the very first â€œBrand Entryâ€ screen is meant to show only the logo and decorative 3D motionâ€”no headline question. Here, we see the â€œVoderâ€ logo plus an additional hero question, which aligns more with the second section (â€œThe Whyâ€ or hero prompt) than with the pure brand-entry stage.  
â€¢ The tagline â€œWhat if your prompts were the source?â€ differs from the specâ€™s prescribed hero line (â€œTell Us What You Want. Let Voder Build It.â€).
